Graphical abstract Green hydrogen production from saltwater electrolysis could be aided by the use of alkaline water electrolyzers, high-temperature water electrolyzers, anion exchange membranes, proton exchange membranes, and anion exchange membranes. Hydrogen has been regarded as a promising renewable and green energy source to meet energy needs and attain net-zero carbon emissions. The electrolysis of seawater to make hydrogen is one of the fascinating developments of the twenty-first century. This method uses abundant and relatively inexpensive seawater, as opposed to freshwater, which is rare and can be prohibitively expensive. In recent years, significant research and advancements have been made in direct seawater electrolysis technology for hydrogen production. However, producing highly effective and efficient electrocatalysts with long-term viability under harsh corrosive conditions remains a challenging and severe topic for large-scale seawater electrolysis technology. There is still a large accomplishment gap in understanding how to improve seawater electrolysis to increase hydrogen yields and prolong stability. It is, therefore, crucial to have a condensed knowledge of the tunable and inherent interactions between various electrocatalysts, covering electrolyzer types and paying particular attention to those with high efficiency, chemical stability, and conductivity. The extensive discussion is structured into a progression from noble metals to base metal compounds such as oxides, alloys, phosphides, chalcogenides, hydroxides, and nitrides, MXene-based complexes with a concise examination of hybrid electrocatalysts. In addition, proton exchange membranes, anion exchange membranes, alkaline water electrolyzers, and high-temperature water electrolyzers were potential contributors to seawater's electrolysis. An extensive assessment of the techno-feasibility, economic insights, and future suggestions was done to commercialize the most efficient electrocatalytic systems for hydrogen production. This review is anticipated to provide academics, environmentalists, and industrial researchers with valuable ideas for constructing and modifying seawater-based electrocatalysts. Keywords Seawater splitting Hydrogen production Electrolysis Electrocatalysts Electrolyzers Techno-feasible analysis Review 1 Introduction Since major decarbonization and de-fossilization are required to meet the 2050 climate challenge targets, all energy sectors will undergo significant transformation over time [1]. The best strategy by 2050 is to create a society with zero greenhouse gas emissions, known as the “European Green Deal,” in which renewable energy sources (RES) play a leading role. In the context of the energy transition, hydrogen is not only a crucial raw material for industry, but it also serves as a sustainable and clean alternative energy source to fossil fuels, which are quickly running out [2,3]. By connecting the transportation, heating, and power sectors, hydrogen helps to reduce global warming and air pollution. The production of hydrogen can be accomplished through a great variety of efficient phenomena, including the recombination of methane, the fossil fuels reforming, photocatalytic splitting of water, and electrocatalysis, including many others [4–8]. According to the available data, the annual capacity for hydrogen generation on a global scale is roughly 70 million tonnes, and a little less than 96% of hydrogen comes from the combustion of fossil fuels (mainly natural gas, followed by oil and coal) [7]. Because of its high efficiency and its potential to couple with renewable energy sources such as solar and wind, water electrolysis is recognized as among the most environmentally friendly and cost-effective techniques for producing hydrogen [7–11]. Even though nature hardly ever has pure water in its natural state, most water-splitting systems used alkaline, purified water as their electrolyte until recently. Since seawater is a plentiful natural resource on our planet, the creation of hydrogen through seawater electrolysis is becoming an increasingly attractive option due to the growing scarcity of pure water [12,13]. It has been discovered that the electrolysis of seawater is an effective technique to produce clean hydrogen energy, which has significant implications for the desalination of seawater [14]. Seawater can be instantly electrolyzed in place of pure water to store clean energy and provide potable water, especially in arid areas [15]. The successful application of seawater splitting technology will also contribute significantly to developing a circular economy. Statistics show that more than 96.5% of the water on Earth comes from the sea (over 1.33 billion cubic kilometers). Electrochemical water splitting generates 142 MJ kg−1 hydrogen gas using readily available seawater rather than fresh water. This method would help reduce the consumption of precious fresh water while simultaneously addressing critical issues like the rising demand for energy and the diminishing supply of fossil fuels such as natural gas, coal, and petroleum [14,16]. Therefore, the electrolysis of seawater presents a feasible opportunity for the generation of hydrogen on a massive scale. Seawater electrolysis has proven to be an effective method for producing clean electricity and high-purity drinking water for island and coastal communities [17,18]. Seawater electrolysis has been receiving increasing attention from researchers recently due to the multiple benefits of splitting seawater. In most cases, the electrolysis of seawater is composed of two separate but equally essential half-reactions: the cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [19–23]. The production of hydrogen from seawater is considered particularly challenging by the scarcity of electro-catalysts that achieve a high level of success for the HER and OER. Since seawater has a naturally low conductivity, electrocatalysts must be very conducive to overcoming the slow HER kinetics [24,25]. As a result of microbes in seawater, poor HER performance is also associated with the development of solid precipitates that block the active sites of the catalyst surface [26,27]. In terms of kinetics, the OER suffers since it is a multi-step process that generates many intermediate products and needs the removal of four protons. Because of this, the development of each intermediate is accompanied by a considerable energy barrier, and as a consequence, a significant overpotential is essential for driving the OER [28–30]. In addition, because of the high intensity of chloride anions in seawater, around 0.5 M, the chloride evolution reaction (CER) will also take place on the anode at a relatively high potential which competes along with the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Due to the abundance of strong chloride anions in seawater, its electrolysis demands electrocatalysts that can withstand chloride corrosion, particularly at the anode. The creation of efficient, cost-effective, and stable electrocatalysts by customizing the morphologies, conductive matrices, compositions, and micro/nanostructures for HER and OER is currently the top priority in light of these challenges in seawater electrolysis for H2 production [31-34]. Several studies show that the performance of most reported electrocatalysts is limited to harsh acidic/alkaline conditions and a very narrow pH range, which makes practical use over a wide range of operating conditions difficult. Due to its essential importance in various contexts, creating electrocatalysts that are effective throughout a broad pH range is a central topic in catalyst development. Several technical application conditions, including those for whole-house water splitting, microbiological electrolysis, and chloro-alkali electrolyzers, must be attended to, (i) understand the mechanism of HER in different environments of chemicals, and (ii) lessen the loss in energy efficiency due to the unavoidable pH variations that occur during ongoing electrolysis in the membrane-separated container and near-electrode area of the device [35]. Significant advances have been made in the fields of electrocatalysts over the past few decades, with some of them having a catalytic activity that even exceeds current state-of-the-art platinum (HER) and iridium and ruthenium oxides (OER), despite their scarcity and expensive cost [36–38]. The increasing number of articles related to H2 generation released over the last two decades proves the expanding interest in this field, as shown in Fig. 1 . Therefore, it is imperative to design a state-of-the-art review of high-performance HER and OER electrocatalysts in seawater for industrial H2 applications. More work would be kept into making highly efficient OER and HER electrocatalysts. In this review, we first looked at how H2 is made from seawater and what problems it poses; we also looked at recent progress in making H2 from seawater by using electrocatalysts and water electrolyzers based on what we learned. In conclusion, the possibility of further technological advancement through seawater electrolysis was also suggested. 2 Carbon neutrality, sustainability, and renewable hydrogen energy There have been several discussions on the history of seawater electrolysis, beginning with the discovery of the phenomenon of the electrolytic split of seawater into hydrogen and oxygen and ending with the development of various versions of techniques to meet the hydrogen demands of a wide range of applications [39]. There is evidence from the scientific literature that water molecules may be electrochemically divided into H2 and O2. However, due to the reactant variation, this reaction can occur through distinct routes at specific pH levels [40], as it has been found that seawater electrolysis consists of OER and HER, which are both based on the electrolyte's pH level [41–44]. It is a continual uphill fight to attempt to break apart water molecules to make hydrogen and oxygen molecules since water is one of the things that is one of the most thermodynamically stable things that exists. To electrolyze water and generate hydrogen (and oxygen), we would first overcome the optimum cell voltage, which is denoted by the letter E and is also referred to as the “electromotive force” [39]. The overpotential is the excess potential more significant than the thermodynamic value of 1.23 V throughout the whole water-splitting process. Specifically, concerning seawater electrolysis, efficiency is often defined in terms of the reaction enthalpy. Under ordinary conditions (standard atmospheric pressure and temperature), Enthalpy and the Gibbs free energy of the water splitting process are G 0 = 237 kJ mol−1 and H 0 = 286 kJ mol−1, respectively [45]. (1) Overall: 2H2O → 2H2 + O2 (E = 1.23 V) The whole process of water splitting might be powered by a battery voltage as low as 1.23 V, indicating that reversible electrocatalysis requires a thermodynamic electrical capacity of 1.23 V. To make this reaction somewhat progressive in the face of potential loss and kinetic restrictions, an overpotential of more than 1.23 V is often required from the cell [46,47]. It is well accepted that one of the most effective methods for enhancing electrocatalytic water splitting is to use suitable electrocatalysts to lower the overpotentials of each half-reaction. One of the biggest challenges for HER is that, during electrolysis of seawater, the pH of the water is constantly changing, rising at the cathode due to HER and falling at the anode due to OER [48]. Even at a low current density of just 10 mA cm−2, reports of pH shift during electrocatalysis vary from 5 to 9, which causes severe damage to the electrocatalysts [49]. Because of this, the cations that are found in seawater can cause precipitations to occur, such as Ca(OH)2 and Mg(OH)2, which then block HER active sites [50]. In addition, several other chemical species can be found in seawater. The typical composition of ocean seawater species, the corresponding redox reactions, and the standard electrochemical potential (E 0) at alkaline and acidic pH levels can be found in the refence [51]. As a result, seawater includes electrochemically active anions that would interfere and compete with the water-splitting electrocatalysis, it is not a viable feed for existing electrolyzer technology. To achieve the electrolysis of seawater over the long term, the issue of extreme pH variation needs to be resolved. There are now two different approaches that may be used to solve this problem: (i) inserting a pH buffer into the seawater electrolysis system to stabilize pH changes, and (ii) designing suitable seawater electrolyzers to extract sediments from the surface of the cathode [18]. Furthermore, specific metallic ions absorbed in salt water, like Cu2+, Cd2+, and Pb2+, would settle on the cathode's surface at the appropriate voltage. This would be in direct competition with HER and dramatically diminish the electrode's lifetime. To attain a high HER specificity in seawater electrolysis, it is vital to limit those unwanted electrochemical reactions in the future by designing a proper catalyst design. Currently, there are two primary methods for producing green hydrogen using seawater: one-step and two-step electrolysis, as shown in Fig. 2 . The two-step electrolysis of seawater in which water is first filtered by the converse osmosis membrane module and then divided. On the other hand, the one-step electrolysis of seawater in which water is electrolyzed just after a simple pretreatment [50]. 3 Reaction pathways and fundamentals of electrocatalytic seawater HER is half of the whole water-splitting reaction that could occur in acidic, alkaline, or neutral situations. It is a two-electron transfer mechanism that generates molecular hydrogen through a series of proton and electron coupling stages. As seen in the following equations, OH− ions are typically the predominant reactants in alkaline media, whereas H3O± ions are the primary reactants in acidic solutions [52-56]. The paths for the electrolysis of water in an alkaline solution are depicted in Eqs. (2) and (3), which are as follows. (2) Anode: 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + 4e− (3) Cathode: 4H2O + 4e− → 2H2 + 4OH− The paths for the electrolysis of water in an acidic solution are depicted in Eqs. (4) and (5), which are in the following order. (4) Anode: 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e− (5) Cathode: 4H±+ 4e− → 2H2 The paths for the electrolysis of water in an acidic solution are depicted in Eqs. (6) and (7), which are as follows. (6) Anode: 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e− (7) Cathode: 4H2O + 4e− → 2H2 + 4OH− Since hydroxyl ions tend to accumulate in alkali conditions, OER has a faster kinetic than HER process [45]. While HER may occur without much trouble in acidic solutions, it is considerably more challenging to achieve effective hydrogen synthesis in neutral solutions with modest overpotentials [57-60]. This is because the HER in neutral electrolytes often requires greater power to produce protons by splitting the water molecules. Fig. 3 shows the Volmer, Volmer-Heyrovsky, and Volmer-Tafel phases involved in the HER model, provided the conditions are neutral [61,62]. The Volmer phase consists of. releasing H* through the breakdown of water. In the Tafel step, the H2 is produced by combining the H* made in the former step. The Volmer-Heyrovsky phase involves the preparation of H2 as a result of the reaction between H2O and H* [63]. First, adsorbed hydrogen atoms are formed at the active centers of the electrode surface by a process called the Volmer reaction (Eq. (8)) that occurs when electrons on the surface of the electrode are bound by protons present in the solution. Hydrogen atoms that have been adsorbed tend to go through a process called a second-phase reaction, in which they take on additional electrons and release H2 gas into the solution (Eq. (9)) when ΔG H* is large. A small value for ΔGH* indicates that H* is being strongly adsorbed; it raises the possibility of the Tafel process along with the production of H2 gas (Eq. (10)) from the combination of surrounding adsorbed hydrogen atoms [63–65]. For acid medium. (8) H± + e− → H* (Volmer step) (9) H* + H± +e− → H2 (Heyrovsky step) (10) 2H* → H2 (Tafel step) The HER in the basic medium starts with the dissociation of water molecules to produce protons. This process involves a combination of the Heyrovsky and Volmer steps; however, unlike the acid solution, the Tafel step remains unchanged [66]. An additional proton dissociation step from water molecules and the generation of hydrogen intermediates (Had) have been reported to slow the HER kinetics under alkaline settings compared to a catalyst operating under acidic conditions [67]. For alkaline media. (11) H2O + e− → H* + OH− (Volmer reaction) (12) H* + H2O + e → H2 + OH− (Heyrovsky reaction) (13) 2H2O + 2e− → 2OH− + H2 (Tafel reaction) According to Parsons, H2O detachment and successive Had adsorption on the catalyst surface are relatively sluggish; therefore, the creation of early hydrogen mediates turns into the rate-determining step (RDS) of the whole HER process [68]. As specific essential varieties/steps (hydroxyl adsorption, Had, and water dissociation) should be adjusted for good execution, alkaline HER is more complicated than acidic HER [69–71]. 4 Development of electrocatalysts for hydrogen production from seawater It is common knowledge at this time that seawater electrolysis can produce hydrogen energy in a manner that is both cost-effective and productive. Recent studies have confirmed that contaminants in seawater are the primary reason for cathodic HER's inefficiency and instability through site corrosion and site blocking at the conductive electrodes [72,73]. Researchers are dedicated to developing catalysts for this process in neutral solutions and are making continuous progress. They found that the electrocatalysts used can be classified into three categories: (1) noble metals; (2) base metals and alloys; and (3) hybrid electrocatalysts. Although the first and second types of electrocatalysts have high catalytic activity, they suffer from high corrosion during seawater electrolysis, resulting in poor stability [74]. In addition, the limited availability of precious metals and their high price make it challenging to implement them on a large scale in the process of H2 production from seawater. Therefore, transition-base metal catalysts mainly include nitrides (TMNs), chalcogenides (TMCs), and phosphides (TMPs), and electrolyzers are used for better results, as depicted in Fig. 4 [75–79]. 4.1 Noble-metal-based electrocatalysts In particular, the ability to consume hydrogen to form M−H bonds catalyzes the water split into H2 and O2. Therefore, a catalyst with a high M−H adsorbed energy and a favorable electrical structure is ideal for enhancing the rate at which seawater is split [80–82]. Due to their excellent electrical conductivity, outstanding stability, and high catalytic performance, noble metals and the alloys of those metals are frequently utilized in the production of HER catalysts. Some examples of noble metals include platinum and palladium [83–85]. These are considered cutting–edge catalysts and highly preferred for use in the electrocatalytic splitting of seawater since these are attributed to optimum M−H adsorption energy and suitable electronic configuration [86,87] . Therefore, creating electrocatalysts based on noble metals in an organized manner and producing them is essential if one wishes to achieve a high level of hydrogen generation efficiency. Numerous research projects have been carried out by scientists in electrocatalytic water splitting using electrocatalysts based on noble metals. Pt occupies the highest point on the volcano plot, signifying that it is the most promising electrode material available, ranking higher than other noble metal-based electrocatalysts [88]. Because of its high price, platinum is not extensively utilized in the industry. However, its price can be reduced by alloying platinum with other transition metals, allowing for wider industrial use [52]. The process of alloying platinum alters the outermost electronic states and the surface area of platinum atoms, which influences the HER process. For instance, Li et al. [89] showed that electrode materials consisting of Pt-Ru-M−decorated titanium (Ti) mesh could be reliably produced by deposition electrochemically. These materials feature a high intrinsic activity, a large amount of surface area per unit volume, and excellent resistance to corrosion. Because of these advantages, electrocatalytic activity toward HER in seawater was greatly enhanced by the Pt-Ru-M/Ti catalysts already in possession. Both the Tafel gradient and the corrosion potential of the catalyst were found to be much reduced upon discovering that alloying Pt-Ru along different transition metals (atoms of Fe, Co, Mo, and Cr) dramatically reduced these values [58]. Pt-Ru-M electrodes displayed considerably reduced overpotentials in the spectrum of 196–256 mV at a present intensity of ten mA cm−2 compared to Pt electrodes (285 mV). Notably, the final Pt-Ru-Mo electrode displayed outstanding stability even after running for 172 h straight without a break [89]. On a mesh made of titanium (Ti), Zheng et al. synthesized the binary alloy Pt-M (M = Cr, Fe, Co, Ni, Mo) using procedures quite similar to those employed in the past. Overpotentials and Tafel slopes of the Ti/Pt-M electrode is noticeably lower than those of the pure Pt electrodes. With a minimal potential start as lower as 0.38 V and excellent stability for more than 12 h of activity, the final Pt(Ni)5 electrode demonstrated the highest catalytic activity level. This was accomplished by altering the stoichiometric ratio of Pt to Ni [90]. Pt-Ni x alloys were utilized as a catalyst for the HER reaction while simultaneously being used to split seawater [91]. In actual practice, it is essential to lower the amount of Pt used while keeping the activity level high. To achieve that goal, Liu et al. established a straightforward method for fabricating a multilayer empty MXene customized (Pt@mh-3D) MXene, a low-Pt catalyst (Fig. 5 a) [74,92]. Relative to widely accessible 20 wt% Pt/C, the Pt@mh-3D MXene synthesized demonstrated much higher performance with robustness during direct seawater electrolysis (Fig. 5b), transforming it into an electrocatalyst that is effective in producing hydrogen while using seawater. The excellent HER performance in seawater was ascribed to the fact that the multilayer hollowed MXene supplied the Pt not only with high conductivity but also with efficient H±/H2O adsorbent and quick ionic/mass accessibility. In addition to platinum, the electrolysis of seawater to produce hydrogen has also been researched using other noble metals such as gold, ruthenium, iridium, and platinum. Both Ni-Au and Ni-Pt alloys were produced on titanium foil by Zhang et al. [93], with 230 and 410 mV as starting potentials; however, the HER process was more catalytically active at the Ni-Pt electrode. By electrochemical deposition on titanium sheet frameworks, Niu et al. [26] also synthesized Ru-Co and Ru-Co-Mo x alloys for H2 generation in seawater catalysis. Ti foil-supported Overpotentials of 387 and 550 mV, respectively, were necessary for Ru-Co alloy electrodes and Ru-Co-Mo x alloy electrodes to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2. It was observed that during seawater splitting, good electrocatalytic efficiency was shown by the electrocatalysts based on noble metals; however, the lack of stability and high costs involved in the use of these electrocatalysts generated concern among the experts. As a consequence of this, experts have focused their attention on improving the electrocatalytic efficiency of these catalysts by using strategies such as surface engineering, defect engineering, and substrate introduction, amongst others [94–98]. In this context, Liu et al. [99] discovered new interface electrocatalyst materials with the help of N/S co-doped carbon nanosheets to serve as the support for Rh nanoparticles (Fig. 6 ). It is indeed exciting to learn that introducing S atoms into N-doped carbon can potentially increase the number of electrons transferred from Rh nanoparticles to the junction of Rh and N/S co-doped carbons, generating an electron-rich interface. In addition, the electron-rich interface can serve as the active site for the HER, which can significantly boost the HER's electrocatalytic performance in natural seawater. 4.2 Non-noble metal-based electrocatalysts Nano-catalysts based on noble metals have been demonstrated to be very active in the creation of hydrogen in natural seawater; however, the high price linked with the poor stability of these catalysts has mainly restricted their employment in the industrial sector. In addition, chlorine evolution takes place at the opposing electrodes, and highly aggressive hypochlorite residues impede the effective areas of the noble metal catalysts. Because of this, the usual noble metal criteria for HER are unsustainable in seawater/alkaline seawater electrolysis, and as a result, they cannot be used [100,101]. As a result, the research and development of stable and active electrocatalysts to split seawater are of the utmost significance for this process. Having base metal catalysts to replace precious metal-based electrocatalysts and the alloy form (base metal > precious metal) is more economically appealing for industrial uses. Zhang et al. contributed to this domain by developing various alloy catalysts from Ni with the chemical composition of Ni-M, where M denotes the elements of Co, Cu, Mo, Au, and Pt. They used Titanium foils in the preparation of these alloy catalysts; they also tested these catalysts regarding their HER performance in seawater [93]. In modern times, a considerable amount of effort has been placed into researching electrocatalysts based on transition metals. Researchers focused their attention on the (oxy) hydroxide, nitrides, phosphides, transition metal oxides, and chalcogenides due to the apparent significance of these compounds, as evident from Fig. 7 . These electrocatalysts have been found to have regulated electrical configurations, great electric conductivities, and intermediate maximized adsorption energies. 4.2.1 Transition metal oxides and (oxy)hydroxide Researchers have shown a great interest in identifying electrocatalysts based on materials other than noble metals that are more efficient in achieving higher electrocatalytic performance during water splitting besides being able to produce low-cost catalysts. Usually, experts prefer using oxides and hydroxides of transition metal as electrocatalysts during water splitting owing to the high intrinsic activity of these compounds [102-105]. However, even with this high performance, the transition metal oxides and hydroxides fail to yield the efficiency required for commercial water splitting. This situation calls for further improvement of electrocatalytic performance. Hence, experts have invested in advancing strategies like electronic structural engineering, defect engineering, metal/substrate combination, and morphology design to enhance the material's electrocatalytic activity [63]. Metallic oxides are considered superior HER catalysts due to their high catalytic activity and diverse crystal structures. Their performance is parallel to that of Pt during natural seawater splitting. But, a considerable improvement in metal oxides is essential to make them effective HER catalysts appropriate for industrial use [52]. According to Lu et al. [72], the performance of transition-metal oxides in seawater by electrocatalytic HER may be enhanced with the help of electronic structural engineering. To develop materials with high electrocatalytic performance, Pyrolysis of the Mn-MOF/Ni-F precursor was used to produce Mn-doped nickel oxide/Ni (Mn-NiO/Ni), which took place in an inert atmosphere. The substrate functions were performed by Nickel foam that released nickel atoms. The released atoms reacted with Mn-MOF producing Mn–NiO/Ni/NF. It's worth mentioning that the Mn-NiO/Ni/NF made in this process depicts better specific surface area, electronic structure, and intense synergistic effect resulting in higher stability and electrocatalytic activity in both neutral electrolytes and seawater. Amal et al. discovered that HER performance of carbon-based NiO/Ni could be significantly improved by employing a controllable method for changing the degree of oxidation of Ni [106]. The electrical structure of the catalyst may also be vastly improved by doping it with noble metal atoms (which are liberated by metal oxides). The use of the oxide of Ru is preferred in HER electrolysis since it is more cost-effective and is attributed to higher binding energy to hydrogen. When it comes to electrocatalytic performance, the geometry of the metal oxide plays a significant role. Numerous defects and exposed surfaces are present in amorphous materials due to their unique arrangement of atoms [107]. An amorphous cobalt-based oxide with an extremely low Ru content, Wu et al. developed the Ru-CoO x /NF [108]. The amorphous form of the material resulted in more active sites for electrocatalytic processes than other materials. Furthermore, the material's internal charge transfer was accelerated by adding Ru components, which led to improved performance. The Ru-CoO x /NF catalyst exhibits the lowest overpotential and the highest HER electrocatalytic activity under both low and high current densities. As shown in Fig. 8 shows that Ru-CoO x /NF has the smallest Tafel slope (28 mV dec−1), which further confirms that it has excellent HER electrocatalytic activity. Yu et al. [109] worked on an anion-assisted performance improvement technique achieved through the rapid and universal screening of electrolyte additives by associating Cl− repellency with the anionic characteristics. In particular, it was discovered that the addition of phosphate ions made it possible to split alkaline seawater at an industrial-level current density (0.5 A cm−2) for 500 h while employing transition metal hydroxides as anodic electrocatalysts. In situ investigations and theoretical simulations further demonstrate that the dynamic anti-corrosion characteristics of surface-adsorbed phosphate ions are attributable to three causes. These include the repelling Cl− ions without appreciably obstructing OH diffusion, inhibiting transition metal dissolution, and functioning as a local pH buffer to compensate for the quick OH consumption under high current electrolysis. In addition to transition metal oxides, it has been shown that transition metal (oxy)hydroxides are also very good at splitting seawater naturally even more so in HER [110,111]. Jiang et al. [112], using electrodeposition, on the surface of NF, heterostructure nanosheets made of NiFe-LDH/Fe-OOH were obtained. As a result of the interaction between NiFeLDH and Fe-OOH, the catalyst could attain significant HER performance in an electrolyte that included 1.0 M KOH and 0.5 M NaCl. NiFe-LDH/Fe-OOH had an overpotential of 181.8 mV when the current density was 10 mA cm−2, and it had an overpotential of 286.2 mV when the current density was 100 mV cm−2. NiFe-LDH/FeOOH showed considerable catalytic activity with excellent stability over 105 hours of operation when subjected to a current density of 100 mA cm−2. Cation doping was discovered to regulate the three-dimensional energy level of electrocatalysts and adjust the electronic structure and intermediates' energy for the adsorption of the surface [111,113]. Zirconium (Zr) is one of the most prevalent elements on Earth, and it may exist in a wide variety of oxidation states. Catalyst electronic structure can be altered, crystallinity can be decreased, and active surface area can be increased by adding Zr4+ ions in a stable oxidation state [114,115]. Liu et al. [114] used nickel foam surface to evaluate the HER performance of layered double hydroxides with a low crystalline structure and Zr-doping. The composite was immersed in 0.5 M NaCl and 1 M KOH electrolyte and placed in a water-splitting electrolyzer. Despite the stable operation time of 20 hours demonstrated by Zr-doped hydroxides, the electrocatalytic performance in seawater splitting is not adequate for commercial usage due to low conductivity, CER, and chloride corrosion. An improvement in the electrocatalytic performance of NiFe (oxy) hydroxides is required for the simultaneous synthesis of hydrogen and desalination of seawater. By applying a treatment to the NF surface, Ren and his colleagues were able to produce a material with a hydrophilic S-doped Ni/Fe (oxy) hydroxide cover and many porosity layers. An effective conductive channel to the electrolyte is provided by the porous substrate structure, which also facilitates electrolyte flow without bubble formation and reduces overall bulk. In this way, the formation of the oxyhydroxide layer ensures structural integrity. The developed material shows low resistance to charge transfer and is also attributed to a more significant number of active positions and a larger surface area [116,117]. 4.2.2 Transition metal nitrides Transition metal nitrides (TMNs) are very good at conducting electricity and resisting corrosion. They have also been shown to be stable for splitting seawater [101,118]. On the other hand, most of the bulk TMNs that have been documented have been found to have HER activity that falls short of expectations due to an inadequate quantity of hydrogen bonding energy [119,120]. As a result, strategies for material optimization, including vacancy engineering, heteroatom doping, alloying, and interface engineering, are typically required to improve their activity [121–126]. For instance, interacting MoN with C3N4 can significantly boost HER activity in alkaline media [127]. Doping Co3N with tungsten and phosphorus, respectively, may cause a change in the kinetics of dehydrogenation, which will increase hydrogen generation [125]. Given the substantial research that has been done on TMNs, it is necessary to attain enough activity and corrosion resistance simultaneously, and more sophisticated modifying procedures must also be created. Jin et al. synthesized atomic-scale Mo5N6 nanosheets by combining an approach for the transition of phases accelerated by transition metals, combined with a two-dimensional lateral synthesis process [101]. Two-dimensional Mo5N6 nanosheets synthesized via rich metal-nitrogen bonding displayed improved HER efficiency in natural seawater and 100 h of durability under high current compared to standard nitrogen-deficient metal nitrides. The performance was significantly superior to the Pt/C benchmark and the other metal nitrides equivalents as shown in Fig. 9 . The electronic structure of Mo5N6 was like that of Pt, which contributed to its exceptionally high activity. The high valence of its Mo atoms was the cause of its stable nature. This high valence made it considerably less vulnerable to active-site poisoning by other ions in seawater, which was the primary factor contributing to its stability. In addition, tinkering with the compounds' stoichiometry is one way that the qualities of TMNs may be improved to make them more desirable. By using this tactic, one may control the electrical structure of the TMN by adjusting the proportion of the total amount of N atoms that are included in the metal matrix [101,115,122,123,125,128,129]. The nitrogen-rich process and the incomplete nitridation process are the two primary methods utilized to control the amount of nitrogen contained in TMNs [130,131]. The nitrogen-rich process has as its goal the embedding of additional nitrogen atoms into the TMN lattice. However, to accomplish this goal, conditions of elevated temperature and extreme pressure are typically required owing to the slow thermodynamics involved [129–133]. Incomplete nitridation is a process that may reduce the amount of metal-nitrogen bonding that takes place in the matrix and promote the production of metal–metal nitride interfaces, each of which typically provides increased conductivity and consequent electrocatalytic activity [121,123,131,134]. Jin et al. used an unsaturated nitridation procedure to create a nickel surface nitride enclosed in a carbon casing (Ni-SN@C). This was accomplished by successfully synthesizing a nickel surface nitride [135]. In contradiction to previous transition metal nitrides or metal/metal nitride heterostructures, Ni-SN@C would not have any observable bulk nickel nitride phase and only had unsaturated NiN linkages on its surface. Ni-SN@C, on the other hand, Ni-SN@C has metallic nickel as its principal chemical ingredient in addition to a unique unsaturated character NiN bond. In basic seawater, the Ni-SN@C catalyst showed an overpotential as low as 23 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which corresponds to a very high current density. This technique not only led to the development of catalysts with the favorable features of metal nitrides, but it also stimulated the redistribution of charges on the catalyst's surface. This caused the catalyst to have outstanding resistance to corrosion and an elevated activity level for HER in seawater electrolysis. 4.2.3 Transition metal phosphides Metal phosphides are a non-precious transition metal-based electrocatalyst that has shown great promise for enhancing electrocatalytic reactions. This may mostly be attributed to their many inborn physiochemical features. Also, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) offer optimal electrical conductivity, decisive coordinating action of metal atoms, and high mechanical stability. TMPs, in contrast, hand, are not particularly prevalent in today's society [136,137]. On the other hand, it has been shown that TMPs have structural similarities with hydrogenase. The metal and P sites in TMPs function as hydride acceptor and proton acceptor centers, respectively; these functions modulate the electronic framework of catalysts and promote reaction kinetics [138,139]. Since chloride ions will cause catalyst corrosion and generate toxic chlorine or hypochlorite, the problem with the design of TMPs is mainly how to enhance their specific oxidation and corrosion resistance. This is because producing harmful chlorine or hypochlorite will result in a sharp decline in efficiency. Researchers have logically engineered the composition and structure of an effective HER catalyst that can instantly electrolyze seawater to overcome these challenges. This has allowed them to develop a solution [140]. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in TMPs as ideal electrocatalysts for splitting seawater for hydrogen production [63,139]. Lin et al. [141] analyzed the robust, broad pH hydrogen evolution electrocatalysis using in-situ doping-induced NiCoP/S nanocrystal lattice strain. The small number of S atoms in NiCoP/S NCs caused a disturbance in the local electronic structure, resulting in the atomic position shift of the nearest neighbor in the protocell and the nanoscale lattice strain. These changes optimized the H* adsorption-free energy and activated H2O molecules, which led to a significantly improved HER performance across a broad pH range. It only required 266 mV vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) and 660 mV vs. RHE to arrive at the current density of 350 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH and natural seawater, indicating the application prospect for high industrial current. In particular, the NiCoP/S NCs displayed better HER electrocatalytic activity than the comical 20% Pt/C at high current density in 1 M KOH and natural seawater. In addition, NiCoP/S NCs demonstrated remarkable performance as a supercapacitor. When constructed into an all-solid-state flexible device, it exhibited a high specific capacity of 2229.9 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 and an energy density of 87.49 W h kg−1, outperforming the performance of the majority of transition metal phosphides. Metal phosphides have excellent electrical conductivity when the correct number of atoms of metal and phosphorus are present in the proper proportions. At pH = 0–1, CoMoP@C displayed catalytic activity that was equivalent to that of 20% Pt/C, while at pH = 2–14, it exhibited catalytic activity that was superior to that of 20% Pt/C at high overpotential [142]. The carbon shell's remarkable ability to absorb protons contributed significantly to the HER's overall performance. In the meantime, the carbon shell on top of the CoMoP core protected the catalyst from corroding, agglomerating, and becoming poisoned by seawater. Because of this, CoMoP@C demonstrated an exceptional HER performance in actual seawater. Similarly, Lv et al. used hydrothermal and phosphorylation methods to create NiCoP electrocatalysts that are porous and feather-like on foam nickel [143]. Additionally, the greater surface area and open, active sites from the spongy geometry and conductive substrate helped discharge the produced H2. In addition, the electrochemical endurance was significantly improved because of the synergistic effect produced by the combination of 3D pore designs, electronic phenomena, and conductive substrates. NiCoP/NF showed outstanding activity and stability in seawater when tested at an overpotential of 287 mV, along with a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Lin et al. [79] conducted electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution across a wide pH range and seawater, synthesized from bundles of Fe-doped Co2P nanorods with high-precision control. By altering the quantity of iron doping, it was possible to produce cobalt phosphides with various crystal phases and morphologies. It was discovered that a molar ratio of 1: 0.5 between cobalt and iron had the best results. Fe doping provided advantageous electrical characteristics and shape, lattice distortion, and a unique coordination environment, all of which improved the HER performance of Co2P over the whole pH range. According to the calculations based on the density functional theory, adding Fe lowered the hydrogen binding strength of Co2P, allowing for an adequate acceleration of the HER kinetics and producing a favorable charge density. An orderly development of core/shell type PSS-PPy/Ni-Co-P HER electrocatalyst was constructed by Tian et al. on copper foil by employing Ni-Co-P as the center and a hybrid polymer of pyrrole with sodium polyphenylene sulfonate as that of the shell. This electrocatalyst was used to generate an HER [144]. The PSS-PPy was used to get optimal results for the Ni-Co-P in terms of its electronic structure, hydrophilicity, and electrical conductivity. Some other carbon-doped nanoporous cobalt phosphide, this time denoted by the symbol C-Co2P, displayed outstanding catalytic activity in an artificial alkaline seawater electrolyte that also included the chlorides NaCl, MgCl2 and CaCl2. The presence of carbon atoms with a high electronegativity and a short atomic radius altered the elemental composition of Co2P. This was accomplished by breaking the Co-H bond and accelerating the HER kinetics. Furthermore, carbon doping enabled the development of C–Hads intermediates, which assist in hydrolysis and hence lower the energy barrier, thus, opening pathways for two-stage hydrogen transport. These pathways were developed as a result of the synthesis of C–Hads as shown in Fig. 10 [145] . 4.2.4 Transition metal chalcogenides Transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) are one of the earliest and most thoroughly researched compounds for the electrocatalytic splitting of water. This is because, in addition to their peculiar properties, considerable activity, and widespread availability, TMCs are also among the substances that were discovered first [146]. Despite these favorable settings, the electrocatalytic activity of TMCs is nevertheless inhibited when they are used in seawater [147,148]. Because of this, it is of the highest significance to examine a broad range of productive tactics that might further boost the electrochemical behavior of TMCs in natural seawater. This research must be carried out as quickly as possible. To accomplish this goal, it is essential to conduct research into a wide variety of efficient methods for improving the electrocatalytic activity of TMCs in natural seawater [63]. TMDs are a form of 2D layer substance with the molecular formula MX2, where M is a transition metal (Mo, W, etc.) that is placed between two chalcogenides X2 (X-S, Se, Te, etc.) with a thickness of 1 nm [149]. TMDs have a transition metal (Mo, W, etc.) as the middle layer and chalcogenides on either side. Because of this, TMDs are seen as viable alternatives for usage in HER electrocatalysis applications [150]. TMDs can perform well in contrast to other noble metal catalysts if we consider their high degree of chemical stability and adaptability across an extensive range of pH values; this is because TMDs can withstand a wide variety of pH levels. Similarly, the cost of TMDs is noticeably below that of noble metal catalysts. The processes associated with the catalytically active sites, reaction limiting factor, and structural regulation of TMDs have been the subject of an investigation by researchers over several years. In contrast, the cost of TMD catalysts is much lower than those made from noble metals. Over many years, research has been conducted on the processes associated with the TMD catalytically active sites, reaction limiting factors, and structural control [151,152]. For instance, Ahn et al., employed hybrid materials consisting of CoS2/rGO (2.3 mg mL−1 GO) that exhibited high electrocatalytic activity for the reaction of hydrogen emission. This activity was shown by the fact that there was a high concentration of GO. The overpotential of these materials was 150 mV vs. RHE, and their Tafel slope was 48 mV dec−1 for CoS2/rGO (2.3 mg mL−1 GO) [153]. Using a modified form of the liquid exfoliation process, Lei et al. [154] generated ultrathin and porous MoSe2 nanosheets for HER in a way that was quite comparable to that described before. MoSe2 has a lower initiation potential of 75 mV dec−1 and a Tafel slope of 80 mV dec−1 because of its ultrathin and porous architectures, which contribute to its increased number of active sites [154]. In addition to developing active sites, significant efforts have been made to optimize the HER electrocatalytic activity by engineering the electronic conductivity of metal chalcogenides. Xie et al. discovered that the insertion of oxygen atoms and adjustable disorder engineering can efficiently tune the electronic structure of MoS2 ultrathin nanosheets, resulting in increased conductivity and HER activity [31]. The better electrochemical performance of the Mo-CoS x skeleton was credited with significant activity in another study, as well as the particular configuration between MoS2 and CoS x , which provides more active sites. These factors contribute to the material's ability to conduct electricity [155]. Qiao et al. developed 3D cobalt selenide catalytic electrodes by placing cobalt foil in a vacuum-sealed ampoule where it undergoes selenization in the presence of selenium powder [76]. By considering the proportion of cobalt to selenium in the catalyst’s mass, they could modify the charge on the cobalt foil and the electrocatalytic activity of the catalysts. When considering the various kinds of cobalt selenide electrodes, the overall performance of the Co-Se4 electrode during the splitting of seawater was the most unique and impressive. At cell potentials of 330 mV, the current density measured in Co-Se4 is 10 mA cm−2, indicating that the molecule has a sufficient number of Se centers. This might be due to the exposed electrocatalytic sites and the quick charge transfer capabilities of the material. The 3D cobalt selenide electrodes were created by combining cobalt selenide (Co-Se) and cobalt nine se eight (Co9Se8) in a single-step calcination method. This procedure included the usage of cobalt foil along with Se powder, as evident from Fig. 11 (a and b), which entails the elemental distribution mapping. It was observed that the mass ratio of cobalt foil to selenium powder affected the charge of the cobalt foil and the electrocatalytic performance of the catalysts produced as a consequence of the reaction. Because it is comprised of active sites and porous channels, the one-of-a-kind three-dimensional structure exhibited a better capacity for transferring charge and moving mass. When evaluating the electrocatalytic performance of different electrode materials for seawater splitting, cobalt selenide electrodes perform much better than their combined Ni/Pt-C and Ni/Ir-C counterparts. While the Ir-C/Pt-C system has higher electrocatalytic performance in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte (Fig. 11c), the Co-Se1/Co-Se4 system has better electrocatalytic activity in buffer solution and seawater (Fig. 11d). Cobalt selenide electrode materials have a strong electrocatalytic potential because of their unique structural properties. 4.3 MXene-Based complexes for HER MXene is a novel two-dimensional material that may be represented as M n +1X n T x (n = 1–3), where M signifies initial transition metals such as Ti, Mo, Nb, Ta, and V, X designates either N or C, and T represents surface groups. MXene is expected to have several applications in the field of nanotechnology. It has been shown that MXene exhibits characteristics that are comparable to those of the three-dimensional substance graphene [156]. MXene is an exciting candidate for use as a catalyst because it possesses a diverse structural makeup, high mechanical stability, high hydrophilicity, and high electrical conductivity [157–159]. To make the most of MXenes potential for catalytic applications, constructing it as a hollow three-dimensional structure is often viable. Because of this, the potential for using MXene will be increased to its fullest. Hollow three-dimensional structures can expose a considerable quantity of active surface area and halt MXene aggregation to a certain degree. This might be accomplished by exposing more active surface area. For instance, hollow MXene with a multi-stage structure increased Pt usage by binding to low amounts of Pt. This was accomplished by using the Pt more effectively. Because of this, the charge's transfer rates, hydrogen intermediates binding, and ion exchange rates for ions increased [73]. When the catalyst was used in an experiment in which it was used in seawater electrolysis, where it outperformed commercial 20% Pt/C catalysts in terms of catalytic activity and stability, minimal overpotential 2D Co x Mo2- x C/MXene/NC electrocatalysts were produced by Wu and coworkers [35]. These electrocatalysts had quicker HER kinetics in natural seawater and throughout the pH range. In natural seawater, it was believed that the excellent catalytic activity, extraordinary durability, and great Faradaic efficiency were all due to the exact interfacial engineering that was present there. Additionally, Yoon et al. [160] produced nitride-titanium carbide MXene via nitriding 2D titanium carbide MXene (Ti2CT x ) at extreme temperatures using NaNH2. Compared to pristine-Ti2CT x , which has an overpotential of 645 mV, the best N-Ti2CT x sample, 11 N-Ti2CT x , has a reduced overpotential of 215 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4. This shows that it demonstrates superior catalytic efficacy against HER. In addition, LSV of 11 N-Ti2CT x explains that the overpotential needed to attain 10 mA cm−2 only increased by 5 mV after a 24 h HER test, which indicates that 11 N-Ti2CT x has outstanding long-term stability in an acidic medium. This can be deduced from the fact that the HER test was conducted for 24 hours. Ti2CT x , which has had its surface modified, has the potential to enhance HER effectiveness and increase its endurance. Wang et al. [161] effectively developed a new electrocatalytic material referred to as VS2@V2C. This material consisted of T-VS2 vertically inserted on a multilayer V2C substrate; VS2@V2C exhibited good catalytic performance in seawater at current densities larger than 100 mA cm−2. The VS2@V2C displayed strong carrier mobility and reduced free energy for hydrogen adsorption. This was made possible by the nanosheet support provided by the VS2, which had S sites at the edges that assisted in the adsorption and release of hydrogen. In addition, Miao et al. [162] developed a composite material consisting of H-MoN NPs and B, N co-doped carbon nanotubes called h-MoN@BNCNT. The B, N co-doped carbon nanotubes encased the H-MoN NPs to prevent the H-MoN NPs from aggregating and to protect the cells from being poisoned. The doping effect of B and N in CNTs and H-MoN NPs had a synergistic effect, which contributed to the development of HER active sites. The experts noted a high performance of H-MoN@BNCNT in seawater-based electrolytes owing to their higher stability and current density; the H-MoN@BNCNT even outperformed the commercial Pt/C. 4.4 Hybrid electrocatalysts for HER During the production of H2 with the help of seawater-based electrolytes, high electrocatalytic performance was reported for metal hydroxides, metal oxides, metal phosphides, and nitrides. In addition, combining the metal hydroxides, oxides, nitrides, and phosphides yields heterogeneous structures with high catalytic activity and the development of hybrid catalyst systems due to solid electronic linkages between molecules. This phenomenon yields the optimum adsorption energy of hydrogen as well as changes in the hybrid electrocatalyst in terms of altered charge distribution [163,164]. Due to these, there has been intensive research into developing effective nanohybrid electrocatalysts for seawater splitting. Improving the electrocatalytic efficiency of TMPs may be accomplished effectively by hybridizing the engineering of TMPs with TMNs resistant to erosion and highly conductive [63]. A sandwich-like array of nickel phosphide (Ni x P) microplates was created by Yu et al. [118] by coating the surfaces of nickel cobalt nitride (NiCoN) nanoparticles with nanostructured HER catalysts. This was done to draw ideas and motivation from the research stated before (NiCoN/Ni x P/NiCoN) was a catalyst with a sandwich-like configuration and a significant specific surface area. Because of this, the catalytic activity of each active site was increased, and high conductivity was provided to facilitate the effective charge transfer. Owing to its outstanding chloride resistance of the internal Ni x P microplate array, which enabled a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of 165 mV, the endurance of (NiCoN/Ni x P/NiCoN) in a natural seawater electrolyte was remarkable. This was made possible because the electrolyte had an overpotential of 165 mV. By handling the nickel precursor in nitrogen surroundings, Huang and colleagues were able to create a hybrid electrocatalyst to promote HER activity. This hybrid electrocatalyst consists of a hydrogen acceptor known as Ni5P4 and a hydroxyl acceptor known as amorphous nickel-hydrogen (oxygen) oxide [Ni2+ δ O δ (OH)2− δ ]. To achieve this objective, the nickel precursor was exposed to an atmosphere composed mostly of nitrogen [165]. Because of the protection provided by the hybridization between Ni5P4 and Ni2+ δ O δ (OH)2− δ , the composite electrocatalyst displayed improved specific surface area and electrocatalytic performance. This protection not only increased water adsorption, but also enhanced hydrogen adsorption-free energy and activated the electron conducting pathway across a wide pH range and in a number of different environments due to the shielding's excellent electrical connection and synergistic suppression of P-Hads bonds as shown in Fig. 12 . The designed hybrid catalysts had an overpotential of 144 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2; however, in actual seawater, it was only 108 mV dec−1. The enhanced performance could be traced back to the synergistic effect that the phosphide and hydroxide had on one another, in addition to the higher specific surface area and the electrical contact. This was the case even though the current density was just 10 mA cm−2. In another study, Gong et al. reported nanoscale Ni metal cores that had been overcoated by a Cr2O3-blended NiO layer that had been synthesized on metallic foam substrates. Regarding the hydrogen-evolution reaction in basic solutions, the triphase material composed of Ni@NiO/Cr2O3 demonstrates superior activity and stability comparable to that of Pt. Hydrogen-evolution catalysts rely on the chemical stability of Cr2O3 to avoid oxidation of the Ni core, retain an excess of NiO/Ni interfaces as catalytically active sites in the heterostructure, and provide for high levels of catalyst stability [166]. Researchers in the field of electrochemical energy conversion and storage created structural hybrid electrocatalysts by enclosing active materials in a protective carbon shell. This technique has been widely used to improve electrochemical performance and durability [167–170]. As a result, carbon-shell-coated hybrid structures could improve conductivity, charge transfer efficiency, and chemical stability [167]. The carbon support stabilizes the metal catalyst with good dispersion and corrosion resistance thanks to its tunable surface chemistry. The charge transfer from metal to the surface was recently reported to be driven by single-walled carbon nanostructured catalysts, which improved electronic conduction [171]. In, addition to the high electrical conductivity, their properties of hydrogen adsorption and d-band electronic density state (similar to that of Pt) exhibit an optimal combination that is considered to be the main factor for the observed high HER activity. For instance, carbon-intercalated metal oxides that act as bifunctional electrocatalysts exhibit strong electrocatalytic activity [172]. For the purpose of electrolytic splitting of seawater, Wang et al. constructed carbon coated nickel–iron nitride microsheet arrays on Ni foam (Ni x Fe y N@C/NF) [173]. It has been discovered that Ni3N@C/NF demonstrates a higher HER activity than Ni3N/ NF does. This is because of the abundant electrocatalytically active sites that result from the porous microsheet arrays. Furthermore, the enhanced mass transfer that can be credited to the desired surface superoleophobicity and superhydrophilicity, in addition to the efficient charge transport that can be attributed to the symbiotic coupling effect between the Ni x Fe y N and carbon coating, the protective effect of the carbon coating and the inherent corrosion resistance of Ni x Fe y N are primarily responsible for the good longevity of the material. In addition, Hu et al. fabricated a Mo2C/MoP hybrid nanoparticle that was encased in co-doped carbon nanofibers containing nitrogen and phosphorus [174]. The Mo2C/MoP electrocatalyst displayed extraordinary catalytic activity and good HER in durability because of its superior structural and compositional advantages. It is important to note that the Mo2C–MoP NPC/CFP-800 was capable of achieving effective HER even in seawater. It was able to produce a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in seawater while operating at an overpotential of 346 mV. In addition, the Mo2C–MoP NPC/CFP-800 only needed an overpotential of 85 or 146 mV, depending on whether the solution was acidic or basic, in order to produce a current density of 10 mA cm−2. In conclusion, there have been numerous instances of metal (hydrogen) oxides, hydroxides nitrides, phosphides, and chalcogenides, in addition to hybrid catalysts, performing admirably in the course of seawater electrolysis reactions. In the electrolysis of seawater, each of these catalysts contributes their own unique set of properties. Oxides of metals often have a low cost and a high degree of stability. Metal hydroxides are distinguished by their low cost, high catalytic efficiency, and distinctive layered structure, all of which contribute to a greater active surface area. In addition, metal hydroxides have a relatively low cost. Metal oxides and hydroxides are the most frequent forms of HER catalysts; but their inherent low electrical conductivity presents a significant barrier. Because of their superior resistance to corrosion, low resistance, and high melting point, metal nitrides have lately emerged as one of the HER catalysts that has been the subject of one of the greatest amounts of research. In addition to their outstanding stability, metal phosphides typically have a higher conductivity when contrasted with oxides and hydroxides. In addition, in order to make the most of the benefits offered by the various types of materials, noble metal alloys, carbon-supported noble metals, MXene-based complexes as well as hybrid materials with different composites or structures have been used as catalysts for HER in seawater as discussed in Table 1 . All these catalysts have their own merits and demerits in seawater electrolysis. 4.5 Electrolyzer design for water splitting In addition to producing highly efficient, long-lasting catalysts, creating a high-performance, low-cost electrolyzer for water electrolysis applications is vital. There are now four main types of water electrolysis systems in use which include alkaline water electrolyzers (AWE), proton exchange membranes (PEM), anion exchange membranes (AEM), and high-temperature water electrolyzers (HTWE) such as solid oxide electrolysis (800–1000 °C) and Ceramic membrane electrolysis, which is capable of conducting protons (150–400 °C) [187,188] as shown in Fig. 13 . 4.5.1 Proton exchange membrane water electrolyzers (PEMWE) In 1960s, the PEMWE systems for seawater splitting were first invented that are based on the solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) concept. Generally, IrO2 and Pt black, which are the cathode and anode catalysts, are the typical components of PEMWE anode and cathode, respectively [189,190]. In this, an acidic membrane, known as a Nafion membrane, is utilized as the solid electrolyte in place of a liquid electrolyte. The membrane is responsible for separating H2 and O2 that are created as a result of the reaction and also conducts H± ions from the anode to the cathode [187]. Mostly, the PEMWE electrolyzer can function at a temperature of 90 °C, a current density of 2000 mA cm−2, and a potential of around 2.1 V [191]. The PEMWE electrolysis offers several advantages, one of which is the capacity to make use of higher pressure on the cathode end of the reaction, while the anode may be run at atmospheric pressure [192]. As no caustic electrolyte is involved, PEMWE electrolysis provides a risk-free processing method. PEMWE electrolysis generates H2 and O2 at a faster rate than alkaline electrolysis due to the acidic character of the electrolyte and the metal surface of the electrodes. This makes the kinetics of the reaction that generates H2 and O2 in PEMWE electrolysis more favorable [193]. As water is supplied to the anode, the local pH of the cathode rises, altering the balance of OER and CER. Meanwhile, as a normal proton-transporter, the Nafion membrane is susceptible to external cationic contaminants, resulting in a decreased proton conductivity [187,194,195]. Furthermore, even if the PEMWE isolates specific contaminants at the anode, cationic species such as Ca2+ and Mg2+ move from the anode to the cathode, leaving salts or metal residues behind. PEMWE systems are becoming increasingly popular in industry as a result of their small size, high system efficiency (52%–69% LHV) at high current density, quick response, dynamic operation (0–160% of the nominal load), low temperatures, and the capability to produce ultrapure hydrogen at elevated pressure (30–80 bar) [188,194,196]. The costs of PEMWE electrolyzer stacks have dropped dramatically over the past few years, and by 2030, they are predicted to be the most widely used technology for producing hydrogen without damaging the environment [197]. PEMWE electrolysis approaches to hydrogen production are still too expensive for widespread deployment, despite the rapid pace of development and the significant potential for future growth. For this reason, further investments in research and development activities from both academia and industry for the purpose of producing electrocatalysts that are both low cost and energy efficient are essential for the future growth of the market. 4.5.2 Anion exchange membrane water electrolyzers (AEMWE) In particular, anion exchange membrane water electrolyzers, also known as AEM water electrolyzers, are potential technology for alkaline seawater electrolysis [100,198]. Because of its relatively cheap cost and excellent performance, a large number of research firms and universities are now participating in this project [199,200]. Between the cathode and anode of AEMWE is an anion exchange membrane (particularly, an OH-bearing membrane), as shown in Fig. 14 [201]. The water supply might come from either the cathode or the anode, or it can come from both ends of the electrode. H2 and OH− are both created at the cathode, and then the OH− makes its way over the membrane to the anode, which converts hydrogen into oxygen [187]. For electrolysis systems that employ seawater, anion interchange membranes to stop the movement of unwanted anions are essential (such as Cl−). It must be considered, as the conflict between Cl− oxidation and OH− might become an undesirable issue. However, according to Strasser et al., alkaline conditions appear to be preferred for limiting Cl− oxidation and resulting in excess oxygen selectivity [18], which makes AEMWE for the direct splitting of seawater, their interest is acceptable. Furthermore, Park et al. developed a non-precious metal electrocatalyst with excellent activity and durability and used it to increase a marketed AEMWE system efficiency [202]. The process of synthesizing NiCo/C, in which a NiCo alloy was assisted on carbon as an electrocatalyst to generate hydrogen at the cathode, and through the generation of oxide through a brief heat treatment under air conditions, a method was developed for raising its electrocatalytic action and durability. The locally formed oxide helped speed up the hydrogen reaction by creating a route for the excess hydrogen to move, and the metal oxide's higher binding dissociation energy enhanced the product's chemical stability. In addition, the excellent performance and stability of the stack of five single cells in which it was tested showed that it might be successfully commercialized. 4.5.3 Alkaline water electrolyzers (AWE) The most cost-effective and well-established method of producing hydrogen at an industrial scale is alkaline water electrolysis [39,203]. It is usual practice to employ nickel-and cobalt-based oxides as the anode and cathode materials in alkaline electrolysis, respectively, using a liquid electrolyte of 30%–40% KOH [204]. The electrolyte is cycled through the electrodes at regular intervals to supply the system with the necessary alkalinity. A porous diaphragm separates the anode and cathode chambers, which do not conduct hydrogen or oxygen but do conduct hydroxyl ions [39,205,206]. Diaphragms are often constructed from polymers like polypropylene and polyphenylene sulphide, or ceramic oxides like asbestos and potassium titanate [206–208]. The cell's positive and negative sides are supplied with an alkaline electrolyte. Just at the cathode, water is broken down into hydrogen and OH−, and then, as illustrated in Fig. 15 , OH− begins to move through the membrane to the anode, which is oxidized to produce oxygen. When compared to PEMWE or AEM membranes, the diaphragm materials (like Zirfon) used in AWE are more physically durable and less prone to blockages. This is because PEMWE and AEM membranes are made of polyetherimide [49,209]. Typical alkaline water electrolysis uses a current density of around 400 mA cm−2, a cell voltage of 1.85–2.2 V, moderate temperatures of 70–90 °C, and conversion efficiencies of 60%–80% [39,187]. In addition to the fact that it does not need a noble metal catalyst for hydrogen production, alkaline electrolysis also has the advantage of being relatively easy to work with due to its lower operating temperatures [210]. Hu's team proved for the first time that nickel phosphide (Ni2P), an efficient hydrogen-evolving catalyst, is also highly active in the OER [212]. As a result, the core-shell (Ni2P/NiO x ) structure withNi2P/NiO x may function as both cathode and anode catalysts for an alkaline electrolyzer (1 M KOH), and at 1.63 V, this catalyst could generate 10 mA cm−2. Liu et al. also revealed the usage of an amorphous CoSe film produced by electrodeposition using Ti mesh, which demonstrated good electrocatalytic activity and stability in alkaline media for both HER and OER. At a cell voltage of 1.65 volts, the AWE with two electrodes produced a water-splitting current of 10 mA cm−2 [213]. Reduced current density and operating pressure severely effect system size and hydrogen generation costs, however AWE systems are widely available, durable, and exhibit comparatively low capital cost since they avoid noble metals and have reasonably mature stack components. In addition, the system's effectiveness and gas purity might be significantly impacted by dynamic operation (frequent start-ups and variable power input) [214]. As a result, the development efforts are concentrated on raising the working pressure and current density, in addition to designing systems for dynamic operation, so that they may work with intermittent renewable sources. 4.5.4 High-temperature water electrolyzers (HTWE) Both proton-carrying ceramic membrane electrolysis (at temperatures between 150 and 4000 °C) and solid oxide electrolysis are variants of HTWE. The distinction between the two lies in the ions that pass through the membranes. Because it performs electrolysis under the influence of thermal energy rather than the more expensive electric energy, the HTWE method is considered efficient and cost-effective. Additionally, the high working temperature accelerates the reaction, which reduces the energy loss produced by the polarization of the electrodes. As a result, the electrolysis process as a whole is more effective [215]. However, the drawbacks of these HTWE systems include high energy consumption, catalyst degradation, severe material restrictions, and significant issues with electrolysis system design and duration compared to low-temperature electrolysis systems [216]. The process of Proton conducting ceramic membrane electrolysis involves the addition of water to the anode. The water undergoes a reaction at the anode to yield H± and O2− atoms. Next, the released protons pass through the ceramic membrane and reach the other electrode. Considering the solid oxide electrolysis (SOCE), water yields steam which undergoes a chemical reaction at the cathode to yield H2 and O2−. Next, the oxygen atom produced at the cathode passes through the ceramic membrane or solid oxide layer to reach the anode and undergoes a reaction to yield O2 [217]. The basic operating principle of SOCE is seen in Fig. 16, at temperatures over 600 °C, all raw materials that enter the cell are in gaseous form. The cell's porous cathode catalyzes the dissolution of water, a gas barrier separates the anode and cathode, a thick electrolyte carries oxygen ions, and a porous anode accelerates their oxidation; all of these components are solids [218]. In SOEC, seawater is heated and evaporated using high-temperature electrolysis, and the resulting vapor is divided. If seawater is heated until it evaporates, the resulting water vapor, free of salt and impurities, may be split by SOEC at a high temperature [219]. This may prevent the adverse impacts of sea salt on the electrolyzer and allow for a more efficient conversion of electrical energy. Although it is the least developed electrolysis technology and is not widely commercialized, systems have been developed and demonstrated on a laboratory scale, and individual companies are attempting to commercialize it because its high operating temperature has the greatest potential for use in industrial-scale seawater electrolysis [220]. As the SOEC ceramic material requires no noble and rare metals as the PEMWE, which makes it potentially cheaper. However, the efficiency of the SOEC process itself is much higher and may come close to reaching 100% because the amount of electrical energy used in the electrolysis process is far lower than the amount of chemical energy contained in the fuel that is generated [221,222]. The theoretical efficiency and rate of hydrogen generation per unit area of SOEC have been proven to be much greater than those of AWE and PEMWE electrolyzers [223,224]. In addition, the high temperatures cause significant material degradation, which is a major obstacle. In order to bring this technology to market, scientists are working to improve the stability of currently used component materials, create brand new materials, and reduce the operating temperature to 500–700 °C (from 650 to 1000 °C) [217]. 4.5.5 Hybrid water electrolyzer (HWE) Electrolysis of costless and infinite seawater is a promising way toward grid-scale hydrogen production without causing freshwater stress [226–230]. Practical potential of this technology, however, is hindered by low energy efficiency and anode corrosion by the detrimental chlorine chemistry in seawater in addition to unaffordable electricity expense. Due to this, in recent years, there has been a surge in research interest in hybrid water electrolysis systems. The use of hybrid water electrolyzers would lower costs by reducing the energy consumption, and some reactions could even add market value by producing economically viable products at the anode [231]. Examples include a hybrid seawater splitting technique proposed by Sun et al. to provide energy-saving, chlorine-free seawater electrolysis for efficient hydrogen production [232]. While the crossing of released OH– to the anode side supply the hydrazine degradation to innocuous N2 and water with lower salinity, this reaction consumes seawater on the cathode to generate hydrogen by HER. In addition to the existing state of the art in seawater electrolysis, it permits the production of hydrogen at ultralow cell voltages but huge current densities without the risk of chlorine dangers and without restricting the amount of hydrogen that can be yielded. At industrial-scale current densities, the HSE, which utilizes NiCo/MXene-based superaerophobic hydrophilic and hydrazine-friendly electrodes, has a significantly lower cost of electricity than AWE. The HSE only needs 2.75 kW h m−3 H2; this electrolyzer allows for the quick breakdown of hydrazine to a residue with a lower concentration, and the extraction of water from seawater with a lower salinity. Moreover, Zhang et al. [233] also reported energy-saving hydrogen production by chlorine-free seawater splitting coupling sulfion oxidation. It yields hydrogen at a low cell voltage of 0.97 V, cutting the electricity consumption to 2.32 kW h m−3 H2 at 300 mA cm−2. Compared to alkaline water electrolysis, the energy expense is primarily saved by 60% with 50% lower energy equivalent input. Benefiting from the ultralow cell voltage, the hazardous chlorine chemistry is fully avoided without anode corrosion regardless of Cl− crossover. Meanwhile, it also allows fast degradation of S2− pollutants from the water body to value-added sulphur with 80% efficiency, further reducing hydrogen costs and protecting the ecosystem. It is also found that connecting a hybrid seawater electrolyzer to a commercial solar cell can harvest the hydrogen from seawater with better sustainability [234-236]. This work may offer new opportunities for low-cost hydrogen production from the unlimited ocean resources with environmental protection. 4.6 Electrolytes and effect of pH Because changes follow the OER and HER in the local pH near the electrodes, it is believed that seawater pH is a significant factor in seawater electrolysis. While the pH of the cathode has been gradually increasing due to HER, the pH of the anode has been decreasing progressively due to OER [48]. Even at a low current density of 10 mA cm−2, such pH change during electrocatalysis is shown to be in the range of 5–9 pH, severely damaging the electrocatalysts [49]. Electrolysis of seawater (not artificially buffered) can result in the precipitation of magnesium hydroxide (Mg(OH)2) when the local pH rises below 9.5, thereby blocking the cathode [237,238]. The administration of electrolytes that support the pH may be necessary to stabilize pH variations [198,239]. Pt is now considered the best HER electrocatalyst, regardless of whether the circumstances are acidic or alkaline. According to volcano graphs depicting catalytic rate against metal-hydrogen (M−H) binding energy, Pt reaches a nearly perfect level of activity, making it a popular choice for PEMWE in which the membrane offers an acidic environment [126,240]. However, Pt is expensive, and alkaline electrolyzers commonly utilize Ni or Ni-based metal alloys (such as NiMo, NiFe, and NiMoCo) for the HER because they are less costly and more stable in low pH conditions [241]. There is a lot of interest in developing novel HER electrocatalysts to function as low-cost replacements for expensive catalysts like Pt [242,243]. They recommend the reader to recent research demonstrating the vast spectrum of highly active electrocatalysts for HER discovered in recent years. The vast majority of these examples have not been tested with water of poor quality or that contains salt. Because of the high local concentration of H± generated by the membrane, PEMWE gives an optimal pH for HER in terms of cathode performance [244]. A PEMWE setup can act as a filtering barrier to keep contaminants from the cathode if a highly selective membrane is present. A PEMWE arrangement, on the other hand, provides a small overpotential window and does not meet the OER operating criteria for preventing Cl2 generation at the anode. Since a successful device for splitting salt water is likely to work in conditions close to neutral to alkaline (pH > 8), the rest of this section will focus on neutral-to-alkaline HER catalysis. Finding HER catalysts that can function well in neutral to alkaline circumstances also allows us to target less expensive earth-plentiful materials like Ni, Mn, and Fe, which are often unstable in acidic environments [245]. Since the OER and HER are both accompanied by local pH changes surrounding the electrodes, it is generally agreed that the pH of the seawater is a significant element in seawater electrolysis. The pH of the cathode has been gradually increasing as a result of HER, while the pH of the anode has been decreasing as a result of OER [27]. They examined how well HER functioned in acidic (pH 0), neutral (pH 7), and alkaline (pH 14) environments and discovered that the neutral pH setting resulted in faster HER Tafel kinetics. A direct comparison between natural seawater and buffered seawater reveals that the latter provides superior performance and stability. There was noteworthy HER performance from MXene and nitride-based electrode materials in seawater across a broad pH range, sometimes even exceeding that of the standard Pt electrode [35,161,246]. In the vast majority of instances, the quick kinetics were seen at conditions that were either extremely acidic or extremely basic.
