MXene-based materials, in contrast to Pt, can withstand the aggressive corrosion caused by its catalytic activity and show remarkable stability. 4.7 Electrolyte additives Seawater without additives can in principle be used to split water, but it will lead to lower efficiencies, as the minute concentration of H±, OH−, or buffer molecules cannot sufficiently transport the OH− and H± formed at the cathode and anode, respectively [247,248]. The resulting local pH differences unfavourable change the thermodynamics of the hydrogen and oxygen evolution half reactions and might cause precipitation of various species such as earth alkali hydroxides [49,249]. Further, the conductivity of pure seawater is low resulting in significant potential losses [27]. To prevent a pH gradient and to overcome the low conductivity, either a buffer, a base or an acid can be added [27,49]. This will increase the cost of the water feed by several orders of magnitude (e.g., price of deionized water < 2 US$ t−1 compared to > 800 US$ t−1 KOH and > 100 US$ t−1 H2SO4) [250,251]. In contrast, if high-purity water is used, the acid and base can remain for a long time in the electrolyzer, and, as only H2O is consumed, it is sufficient to simply add relatively cheap high-purity water without additives. Such an operation with seawater is challenging as it will continuously increase the concentration of the seawater impurities in the electrolyzer until they precipitate. The usage of a solid electrolyte membrane can potentially avoid additives; however, currently, such membranes are sensitive to impurities that block the ion exchange sites resulting in membrane deactivation and/or high maintenance costs [49,198]. Electrochemical chloride corrosion engineering was used by Wu et al. in order to create an effective and stable NiFe(oxy)hydroxide catalyst (NFF-S3) on NiFe foam nickel [252]. This study demonstrated that appropriate electrolyte additives (for example, F−, PO4 −3, and WO4 −2) can effectively build Cl-phobic layers on the surface of the catalysts and suppress stability degradation caused by metal leaching [253]. An anion-assisted performance improvement technique was developed by Yu et al., They accomplished this by the rapid and universal screening of electrolyte additions by correlating Cl− repellency with the anionic features of the additives [109]. In particular, it was found that the incorporation of phosphate ions allowed it to split alkaline seawater at an industrial-level current density (0.5 A cm−2) for a period of 500 h while making use of transition metal hydroxides as anodic electrocatalysts. This was made possible by the fact that phosphate ions enabled the use of transition metal hydroxides as anodic electrocatalysts. Investigations conducted in situ as well as theoretical simulations provide further evidence that the dynamic anti-corrosion features of surface-adsorbed phosphate ions can be attributed to three different reasons. In addition to this, it can act as a local pH buffer to compensate for the rapid consumption of OH− that occurs during high current electrolysis, it can also prevent the dissolution of transition metals, and it can absorb Cl− ions without considerably blocking the diffusion of OH−. 5 Techno-feasible analysis 5.1 Techno-economic analysis Since the earliest uses of process systems engineering, the term “techno-economic analysis” (TEA for short) has been used a lot [254]. When evaluating a process's economic and technical performance, it is helpful to employ this method since it provides a wider understanding. It requires assigning a numerical value to the design of the manufacturing plant's process and calculating how much money the plant generates and how much it costs to operate it. Because H2 will be competing with several other options in the international energy market, this study's primary objective is to determine how to manufacture it at the lowest possible levelized cost [52]. It has been discovered that hydrogen can function as a replacement for fossil fuels on a planet that is attempting to decarbonize itself. As the name suggests, “green hydrogen” refers to the pure state of H2 that produces no carbon emissions and is produced through the utilization of renewable energy sources [255,256]. Water splitting is one of the methods for hydrogen production, and when combined with renewable energy sources, it offers the most environmentally friendly production methods. Although water-splitting technology is cutting-edge, cost-effective, and can generate sustainable energy, H2 production at commercially feasible prices has proven highly challenging [257]. Hausmann and colleagues recently addressed the economics of direct seawater splitting in Energy & Environmental Science, comparing it to a two-step scenario with a reverse osmosis plant to initially generate potable water [251]. It has been found that direct seawater splitting has substantial drawbacks as it is less promising than the two-step scenario. The authors arrive at the conclusion that the capital and operating costs of the initial purifying of seawater are only a fraction of those that are associated with the electrolysis of pure water based on the current technologies, efficiency, and costs of reverse osmosis. This conclusion is reached on the basis of the information that is available. It would appear that this is a scenario where there is no room for debate; given the state of technology today, direct seawater electrolysis does not make economic sense when there is already a desalination plant in operation. For both direct and indirect seawater electrolysis, water intake and a pre-treatment (e.g., filtration) units to remove solids are required [258]. For a RO unit, the key parts are a high-pressure pump and a membrane module which feeds the pre-treated seawater to the water selective membrane, where demineralized water permeates and a concentrate containing the retained salts are produced [259]. In comparison, an electrolyzer generally is comprised of a gas collector and two electrodes separated by a gas separator (membrane or diaphragm) which is more than an order of magnitude more expensive than a RO membrane [260]. Hence, a realistic estimation of the future capital costs of an electrolyzer is more challenging. The electrolysis of seawater directly has been the subject of a large amount of research over the past few decades. The direct seawater splitting technique is still in its infancy and is a long way from being ready for commercialization, despite the resources and efforts that have gone into creating this technology [51,261]. More efficient power recovery devices, and process optimization of reverse osmosis (RO) systems, have led to decreased energy demands, capital (CAPEX), and operating costs (OPEX) associated with the desalination process, particularly via seawater reverse osmosis (SWRO) [262]. It has been determined that the efficiency with which this task is carried out is of the utmost importance, and even a one percent increase in efficiency could result in savings of billions of dollars [263,264]. In addition, the devices used in this process have limitations associated with high electricity consumption, device complexity, the durability and lifetime of the PEMWE fuel cells, and the production costs per kilogram of H2. The experimental methods involving wind, solar, biomass, etc., are the furthest from being economically or commercially competitive in terms of cost [265]. In light of the constraints outlined in this section, an appropriate technology that is not prohibitively expensive must be utilized. When trying to figure out how much it will cost to produce H2 and what technical and economic cost-competitiveness targets to set, this whole conversation is a tremendous techno-economic evaluation tool at your disposal. 5.2 Techno-policy analysis As was demonstrated in the sections of this article that came before this one, H2 possesses several benefits that other types of energy sources do not. It is a renewable source of energy that produces no carbon emissions, making it friendlier to the environment than fossil fuels (coal and petroleum) [266-268]. As a result, governments are developing plans to boost H2 production in comparison to other fossil fuels and to assess the potential of different energy sources in light of efforts to reduce GHG emissions under the Kyoto Protocol and other country-specific initiatives, the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and the Paris Agreement [269–272]. Furthermore, the European Green Contract is dependent on the goal of achieving climate neutrality in Europe by the year 2050 [273]. One of the treaty's core principles is to emphasize energy conservation and the development of a power system based primarily on renewable sources. Promoting renewable energy sources such as storage, biomass, and energy conversion are critical components for achieving this goal. One of the primary goals of policymaking is to emphasize energy conservation and the development of a power system based on renewable sources. The use of renewables, such as wind or solar, can make this a clean and sustainable method of producing hydrogen via seawater electrolysis [274]. In order to accomplish this objective, it is essential to encourage the regulation of the production of renewable resources and to put in place a system that provides origin assurances for these resources [275]. Utilizing the aforementioned forms of renewable energy has the potential to make the electrolysis of salt water into hydrogen, which may then be manufactured economically in a number of different countries. As a result, Norway possesses significant wind energy resources; yet, the country is only utilizing a small portion of those resources at the moment. This is due to the fact that the country's remaining hydropower potential is considerable and is more likely to be developed in the near future [276]. The best wind resources in Norway are located either offshore or near the coast, where there is only a minimally constructed power grid [277]. A hydrogen production economy could be developed in Norway by utilizing the offshore wind energy that Norway has to offer in order to produce hydrogen either offshore or close to shore. This would open up the possibility of exploiting wind resources while also meeting Norway's political goals of reducing greenhouse gas emissions at the same time. Norway developed their regulations for the production of hydrogen from the electrolysis of seawater with these resources in mind. It has been found that for the offshore-based approach, seawater brine electrolysis would be a promising choice if it can handle the impurities or if water treatment technologies advance to produce usable water with less cost and increased efficiency. The main products of brine electrolysis are part of the chemicals used for water treatment in desalination plants. This could potentially be a solution to produce more hydrogen while increasing the systems functionality by providing water purification and demineralization processes with their necessary mass flows, perhaps also by combining different electrolysis technologies on a platform. The assessments done further investigated and ideally simulated. The treatment of sea water and use of treated water further assessed and tested in laboratory conditions to quantify the need of chemicals for purification. In addition, Portugal's national H2 plan has made it a global leader in the promotion of eco-friendly H2. Using renewable gases in the natural gas grid is just one example of how this plan facilitates an industrial policy centered on H2 generation, storage, transit, and consumption along the value chain [275]. To further decrease the operational costs of seawater electrolysis, several different methods have been spotlighted as crucial to attracting the necessary commercial commitment to reduce the expense of water pretreatment while maintaining excellent electrolytic cell performance and service life. Specifically, these approaches have been highlighted as crucial to attracting the necessary commercial commitment to reduce the cost of water pretreatment. This will be significantly made easier by developments in electrolysis technique, which will make it possible for water with a purity level lower than ultrapure water to be consumed in a practical setting [50]. To satisfy the ever-changing requests for policy help, transition plans must be industry-specific [278]. If certain national and international policies are adopted, many countries with renewable resources have a great potential to produce hydrogen through the electrolysis of seawater on commercial scales by imposing taxes and supporting the use of clean technology. In order to effectively control the risks associated with investments, the formulation of new policies is necessary [279]. 5.3 Practical implication of hydrogen production from seawater Seawater electrolysis is a critical enabling technology for H2 production that has a long history and has become industrialized and mature in recent decades [280]. Many kinds of electrolyzers have been developed up to this point, as documented in the literature mentioned above. Because Zdansky/Lonza constructed the first pressurized AWE in 1948 [281], it is anticipated that it will play an essential role in the “hydrogen economy” of the foreseeable future [282,283]. Nonetheless, there are significant challenges to overcome in terms of technological development and market and policy conditions to implement a functional hydrogen economy [184,284]. One of the obstacles that must be overcome in terms of the policy is the need to ensure that the generation of hydrogen considers sustainability issues [285]. Multiple studies demonstrate that H2 energy is a sustainable energy source superior to other energy sources in terms of technological efficacy, economic viability, and environmental impact. According to the available statistics, U.S. demand for hydrogen is expected to rise from 11.7 million metric tonnes in 2014 to over 15 million in 2019 [263]. Chile has also proposed a strategy dedicated solely to green hydrogen exports. It has some of the world's best solar (northern desert) and wind energy resources (Patagonia in the south). Chile anticipates achieving 25 GW of electrolysis with the lowest hydrogen cost in the world (USD1.5/kg) and exporting USD 2.5 billion worth of hydrogen and derivatives annually [256,286]. Four primary objectives have been identified to achieve these goals: (i) domestic and international market development, (ii) standards, (iii) social and local development, and (iv) capacity building and innovation [287]. Even with all the work that has been done, there are still significant obstacles to commercialization, such as the high capital costs of electrolyzers and needing to know what the future holds for them [280]. Political support for H2 generation by seawater splitting may be enhanced if the costs associated with that technology could be reduced. This paradigm's commercialization might be accelerated significantly by indirect taxation or direct subsidies from the government [288]. A significant amount of research still needs to be done on developing technologies to develop the most effective catalytic systems. 5.4 Socio-technical analysis Traditional methods, such as fossil fuels, supply approximately 96% of the hydrogen produced in global markets. This energy supply comprises three components: 50% from natural gas reforming, 30% from oil refineries, and 18% from coal [289]. Using the methods described above results in emissions of between 2.5 and 5 tonnes of carbon dioxide per ton of hydrogen produced [290]. The remaining 4% of H2 can be obtained from water through electrolysis; this method has led to socio-economic stability when the necessary power for the electrolyzer is done through renewable energies [291]. Because the electrolysis plant's operation will require a certain amount of human presence, this indicates that employment opportunities will be created (social benefit). Nevertheless, the workspace presents a number of dangers that, if they materialize, could result in accidents at work, which would drive up the process's overall cost (social cost). These dangers need to be mitigated as much as possible and eradicated if possible [52]. The risk of any harm or injury being reflected on workers should be evaluated using criteria that belong to the social factor and are specific to each technology [292,293]. Due to the measurement difficulty, this criterion will also be evaluated using qualitative comparisons based on the information from the preceding section [52,294]. 6 Advantages and current challenges related to H2 production The electrolysis of freshwater to produce hydrogen has been shown to be effective in the past; however, the freshwater resource is limited, and the majority of it is either frozen or in the form of chemosynthetic water. This makes it difficult to use electrolysis to produce hydrogen. On the other hand, seawater, which makes up 96.5 percent of the earth's resources, is readily available all over the world. There is great potential to conserve fresh water and use seawater as an electrolyte for the production of hydrogen through the electrolysis of water. In recent years, there has been a rise in interest in the electrocatalytic synthesis of H2 using seawater [24,295,296]. The electrolysis of seawater is a potential approach for low-cost and large-scale hydrogen production. Despite the promising future of H2 generation by seawater electrolysis, numerous researchers have dealt with less-than-ideal outcomes due to adverse parameters, as shown in Fig. 17 [52]. The challenges associated with seawater electrolysis prevent its practical application; unlike fresh water, its solutions are crucial. A crucial component inhibiting the electrocatalytic process is the sluggish HER kinetic caused by the neutral electrolyte's inherently low conductivity which is among the limiting factors [14,297]. In addition, Because of the presence of up to 3.5 wt% salts and a wide variety of metal ions, seawater electrolysis is not as effective as it could be. These salts and ions can take part in a number of electrochemical processes that compete with those required to produce HER at the cathode. Also, the presence of bacteria and microorganisms in seawater may substantially affect the electrocatalytic system due to the production of insoluble precipitates, such as magnesium and calcium hydroxide, which can cover the surface of active sites and destroy HER electrocatalysts [14,71,173,175]. During seawater splitting, the active areas of electrocatalysts for both HER and OER get occluded and corroded, making their long-term stability questionable. Another significant barrier that must be overcome in seawater electrolysis is the presence of CER. This compound is often found on the anode, competing with OER for electrons at relatively high overpotentials and impeding HER. Very high alkaline concentration imposes expensive expenditures and causes scale deposition on the cathode. Due to the risk of electrode degradation by high chloride ion concentrations and suspended particles, the development of seawater electrolysis is hindered [71,76,298]. The generation of hypochlorite is another reaction that takes place under alkaline conditions [14]. As for the CER in a basic solution, the chlorine will react with OH to form hypochlorite with an onset potential that is 490 mV higher than that of the OER. As a result, in order to avoid the formation of hypochlorite, highly active OER catalysts are required to drive large current densities at the overpotential below 490 mV. As a result, in order to get around this obstacle, the development and production of highly active OER and HER electrocatalysts, as well as the application of Cl-blocking layers on top of the catalyst, are all solutions that are considered to have a good chance of being successful and could result in high OER and HER selectivity [299–301]. 7 Conclusions and future recommendation As seawater is an infinite resource on Earth; therefore, the creation of H2 through electrolysis of seawater can help to alleviate the energy problem to some degree. In the last few decades, a significant amount of effort has been put forth to render the generation of H2 commercially practical by developing the most effective electrochemical systems and very efficient and exceptionally stable catalysts. This article comprehensively assesses the present knowledge on HER electrocatalysts for seawater electrolysis. Numerous in-depth analyses have been analyzed on the electrolyzers, process setup, and reaction chemistry associated with H2 production as well as the performance of the catalyst which include noble-metal-containing electrocatalysts and non-noble metals such as metal oxides (hydroxides), metal nitrides, and metal phosphides. Most reported catalysts lack the catalytic activity and stability necessary for practical application, and progress in this field has been exceedingly slow; therefore, seawater splitting remains in its infancy. We believe that further work needs to be done in the following areas to attain high-performance seawater electrolysis: as the electrolysis of seawater to produce hydrogen gas is a difficult task, especially when employing a catalyst comprised mostly of low-cost components. Designing and fabricating highly active electrocatalysts capable of inhibiting unwanted electrochemical reactions linked to pollutants is essential. The electrocatalysts used in seawater electrolysis must also be highly stable against oxidation by Cl2, ClO2, and other similar compounds. As a result, nanostructured catalysts need to be developed that can ensure low energy consumption, high impurity tolerance, high stability, high HER efficiency, low cost, and low susceptibility to corrosion. For profound insight into the reaction processes of seawater splitting, it is essential to develop sophisticated characterization methods, such as in situ microscopy, spectroscopy, and chromatography, to build and scale up innovative catalysts and electrolyzers to fulfill the need for H2 generation at an industrial scale. By keeping in view, the techno-feasible research and the hurdles we faced in H2 production from seawater splitting, the attention must be paid for designing the best electrolytic systems, the use of experimental test platforms, the execution of long-term testing, and the collection of crucial performance data are some of how the faradaic efficiency of hydrogen generation by seawater electrolysis may be raised. The electrolysis of seawater to create hydrogen is a field of research that will soon make significant advancements due to meticulous and in-depth material evaluation and it is predicted that a breakthrough will be made in the near future following extensive study and improvement of electrocatalyst systems. Obaid Aldosari: He completed his undergraduate studies at King Saud University (1999-2003). He holds an MSc. (2009-2010) in Chemistry from Manchester University. He then studied for his PhD (2011-2014) under the supervision of Professor Graham Hutchings at Cardiff University, in the area of Heterogeneous catalysis. In 2015, joining the School of Chemistry at the College of Science, Tabuk University. In 2016, he moved into the School of Chemistry at Majmaah University and was promoted to Associate Professor of Physical Chemistry in 2020. He was Head of the Chemistry Department and Vice Dean for Academic Affairs (2016-2018). In 2018, He worked as a consultant to Vice-Rector for Graduate Studies and Scientific Research. His current research focused on the design of heterogeneous catalytic materials for applications such as the oxidation of CO, and methane, the conversion of CO2, the splitting of water, hydrogen production, and water treatment. He has publications in international conferences and journals. He has attended numerous conferences and presented in many seminars. Ijaz Hussain: He received his degree Master of Philosophy (MPhil) in chemistry from Forman Christian College (A Chartered University). Under the supervision of Professor Dr. S.E. Benjamin, he joined Pakistan Space & Upper Atmosphere Research Commission (SUPARCO) to conduct research on satellite data application in net primary productivity. Under the direction of Professor Dr. Aishah Abdul Jalil, he completed his doctoral studies in Chemistry in the year 2020. His doctoral research focused on the development of metal-loaded fibrous mordenite zeolites for carbon monoxide methanation. He is currently employed as a post-doctoral researcher at King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals (KFUPM), Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, in the Center for Refining & Advanced Chemicals of the Research Institute. He has taken part in numerous international conferences and seminars and he is a member of American Chemical Society. In the field of heterogeneous catalysis for energy and environmental applications, he is the author of over 40 papers that have been published in scientific journals with a high impact factor. His current research focuses on the design of heterogeneous catalytic materials for applications such as the oxidation of methane, the conversion of CO2, the electrochemical reduction of CO2, the dry reforming of methane, and the splitting of water for hydrogen production. Zuhair Omar Malaibari: Immediately after completing his Ph.D. degree from the University of Waterloo in Waterloo, Canada, Dr. Zuhair joined King Fahd University of Petroleum & Minerals (KFUPM), Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. He is now an associate professor at the chemical engineering department and he is affiliated with the center of the Center for Refining & Advanced Chemicals of the Research Institute. Dr. Zuhair’s research interest is in catalyst synthesis characterization and evaluation. His research projects cover the applications of catalysis science in oil and petrochemical industries, hydrogen production, CO2 conversion to valuable chemicals, and synthesis of carbon nanotubes. His research work was presented at international conferences, and he also patented some of his distinguished scientific findings. Throughout his career, Dr. Zuhair has demonstrated high academic leadership in teaching, research, and administrative services at a variety of levels. His contributions encompass the academic discipline, the institution, and the national community.

coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen has been regarded as a promising renewable and green energy source to meet energy needs and attain net-zero carbon emissions. The electrolysis of seawater to make hydrogen is one of the fascinating developments of the twenty-first century. This method uses abundant and relatively inexpensive seawater, as opposed to freshwater, which is rare and can be prohibitively expensive. In recent years, significant research and advancements have been made in direct seawater electrolysis technology for hydrogen production. However, producing highly effective and efficient electrocatalysts with long-term viability under harsh corrosive conditions remains a challenging and severe topic for large-scale seawater electrolysis technology. There is still a large accomplishment gap in understanding how to improve seawater electrolysis to increase hydrogen yields and prolong stability. It is, therefore, crucial to have a condensed knowledge of the tunable and inherent interactions between various electrocatalysts, covering electrolyzer types and paying particular attention to those with high efficiency, chemical stability, and conductivity. The extensive discussion is structured into a progression from noble metals to base metal compounds such as oxides, alloys, phosphides, chalcogenides, hydroxides, and nitrides, MXene-based complexes with a concise examination of hybrid electrocatalysts. In addition, proton exchange membranes, anion exchange membranes, alkaline water electrolyzers, and high-temperature water electrolyzers were potential contributors to seawater's electrolysis. An extensive assessment of the techno-feasibility, economic insights, and future suggestions was done to commercialize the most efficient electrocatalytic systems for hydrogen production. This review is anticipated to provide academics, environmentalists, and industrial researchers with valuable ideas for constructing and modifying seawater-based electrocatalysts.
